According to the National Cancer Institute, the number of women getting mammograms has dropped over the last five years.
Breast cancer will kill 40,000 women this year and be diagnosed at another 178,000.
The steep decline in screenings has health professionals worried.
For more, we turn to Dr. Ivan Walks.
He's former chief health officer for the District of Columbia and NEWS & NOTES resident medical expert.
Welcome back.
Good to be here.
Thank you.
So this seems perplexing.
What accounts for this drop in screenings?
We have - it's like so many other things.
We have a number of factors.
Very quickly, one of them is that folks are more comfortable.
Folks think that maybe they don't need to go and get screening because the overall rates are down.
So there's that sort of a comfort factor.
One of the things that's really concerning to me, though, is that it's hard to get the mammogram done.
And a lot of people are talking about the fact that there are fewer opportunities.
If you just want to make an appointment, it may take months to get one done.

So you've got the access issue, and then another one that a lot of folks are talking about is the fact that now that we know that hormone replacement therapy for women who have gone through menopause, now that's not really not as frequently recommended and folks are doing that, that was one of the things that made women worry about breast cancer.
So some of the thinking is, if you're not doing hormone replacement therapy, maybe you aren't going to your doctor as much and maybe you don't think that you need to go and have a mammogram done.
All reasons why this could be resulting in a decline, and the decline is a significant concern.
How much do people know, for example, about the causes of breast cancer?
There are different kinds.

And I've read a little bit about how some kinds are very genetically linked - if your mother or if your mother and grandmother and sister had breast cancer - but other ones, I suppose, are not quite as clearly tracked.
I think that overall, there is a - what you're raising is the whole health education piece.
For example, a large part of that is men that have breast cancer.

So there's a lot of information that folks need to get, and it goes back to, do you have a relationship with a primary-care doc - whether that's your OB-GYN or whether that's a family-practice doc - who can take a good medical history and let you know what may put you at higher risk genetically, let you know what may put you at higher risk culturally and socially.
For example, African-American women tend to have some risk factors that are culturally based.
Obesity is one of the huge problems within the African-American community, and it's also one of the huge risk factors with respect to breast cancer.

There's all sorts of issues with managed care and with how many people have good insurance.

Enrollment may begin in Medicare's new prescription drug benefit next Tuesday.
This week, Medicare officials finally got a crucial program running on their Web site.
It's supposed to help people pick a drug plan, but a new survey finds that it's going to take a lot more than a fancy computer program to help seniors sign up.
NPR's Julie Rovner reports.
It's different in different parts of the country, but generally, Medicare beneficiaries have more than 40 separate choices for prescription drug coverage.
Medicare officials hope their new Web program will help seniors succeed at sorting through all their drug coverage options.
Earlier this week, Medicare's Mary Agnes Luareno demonstrated the program for reporters.
She was searching for a plan for a fictitious Iowa widow named Mary Jones, who takes three drugs to treat her diabetes and high blood pressure.
At first, the task seemed relatively straightforward.
And you can see here we have the pharmacies that are available in this plan's network in this geographic area.

So if she just wants to click on the preferred pharmacies, she uses Walgreens, so she can skim down and see that, yes, Walgreens is a plan--is a pharmacy that's in this plan's network, and they are a preferred pharmacy.
But things quickly got complicated, especially when Luareno started looking for Mrs. Jones' specific medications.
The plan that the program said was the cheapest didn't even cover her diabetes drug.
And you can see here with the Glucophage, it has the two little asterisks saying, `This drug is not on the plan's formulary.

So even though this was the least expensive plan for her that gives her the most savings, this particular drug was actually not on the plan's formulary, meaning that she would pay the full cost of that drug.
So the best plan for Mary Jones doesn't pay for one of her three daily medications, and that's hardly the only complication.
In some cases, the Web program has footnote instructions to follow.
Deane Beebe of the Medicare Rights Center found one.
It explained that there may be rules, such as prior authorization, quantity limits or step therapy in order to receive my drug, and so it asked me to call the drug plan to find out more about that.
Which didn't turn out to be easy, either.

I was on hold for the first 10 minutes, and then I did finally speak with somebody who said to me that it was a very good idea for me to call and ask these questions, but he was unable to give me an answer.
He then patched me through to another line.
I waited for an additional 30 minutes, but nobody ever came on the line, and I had to hang up.
Still, Medicare head Mark McClellan says the Web program is a valuable tool.
It can tell any Medicare beneficiary what they'll pay for an individual drug at almost any pharmacy in America.
